The additional data has been obtained from the commercial product Geolytics Estimates premium 2010, which contains current year estimates of demographic and other variables down to the county, or zip code level. In particular, our controls labeled ÃÂ¢Demographic CompositionÃÂ¢ include: population density, median age, the share of residents that is white, black, Hispanic, Asian, or of any other race, and median household income. Those labeled ÃÂ¢Composition of WorkforceÃÂ¢ include: the share of the workforce in construction, manufacturing, retail, or ÃÂ¯nance. And ÃÂ¢Unemployment RateÃÂ¢ refers to the estimated unemployment rate within a zip code. County denotes the FIPS code of a respondentÃÂ¢s county of residence.

Previous Earnings denotes a respondentÃÂ¢s weekly earnings on the job from which she was displaced. The information for this variable stems directly from Displaced Workers Survey. We use the edited variable that is released with the data and discard observations with reported weekly earnings below $100 or above $8,000. Year denotes the year in which the survey was administered, i.e. 2008 or 2010. State is the FIPS code for a respondentÃÂ¢s state of residence. Previous Industry corresponds to the ÃÂ¢detailed industry recodeÃÂ¢ with respect to a respondentÃÂ¢s job from she was displaced. The variable is released as part of the DWS.

AFQT denotes an individualÃÂ¢s standardized score on the Armed Forces QualiÃÂ¯cation Test. We standardize test scores (to have mean zero and a standard deviation of one) by age at the time the test was taken. 44 Currently, the NLSY website is located at ÃÂ¯http://www.nlsinfo.orgÃÂ¯. 45 The NLS Handbook 2005 is available online at ÃÂ¯http://www.bls.gov/nls/handbook/nlshndbk.htmÃÂ¯. Current Hourly Wage gives a respondentÃÂ¢s hourly wage at the main job she holds at the time of the survey, i.e. the CPS job. The variable is taken from the work history ÃÂ¯le. We discard observations with reported hourly wages below $5 and above $100.

Previous Wage denotes the a respondentÃÂ¢s hourly wage at the main job she held at the time of the previous survey. The variable is taken from the work history ÃÂ¯le. We discard observations with reported hourly wages below $5 and above $100. Year denotes the year in which the survey was administered, i.e. 2000, 2004, or 2006.

Previous Industry is a set of twelve indicator variables (based on 3-digit 1970 Census classiÃÂ¯-cations) denoting the industry of a respondentÃÂ¢s previous employer, i.e. the employer at the time of the last survey.

Employment is only considered for the current (or most recent) CPS employer, and only if the respondent is working at the job in the week of the interview. In case of two concurrent jobs, only the job at which the respondent works the most hours is consideredÃÂ¢regardless of whether it is 46 Altonji and Pierret (2001) also drop 805 respondents who left school before 1978 for whom they could not reconstruct their work history.

Hourly Wage denotes a respondentÃÂ¢s real hourly wage at her CPS job. The raw variable is taken from the work history ÃÂ¯le. To convert nominal into real wages we use the Personal Consumption Expenditures: Chain-type Price Index (PCECTPI) constructed by the U.S. Department of Commerce: Bureau of Economic Analysis, and set 1987 as the base year. Following Altonji and Pierret (2001) we discard wage observations with real hourly wages below $2 and in excess of $100. Tenure denotes a respondentÃÂ¢s total tenure (in years) with the employer at her CPS job.

Urban Residence is an indicator variable equal to one if the respondentÃÂ¢s residence at the time of the survey is urban, and equal to zero if it is rural. 47 For 32 observations included in the sample of Altonji and Pierret (2001) the work histroy ÃÂ¯le of the NLSY79 did not contain a valid wage. We suspect this may be due to later revisions and consistency checks applied to the raw data.
